block.p: Israeli Push in West Bank; Criticism of Bush Grows Israeli soldiers and tanks poured into the West Bank in an extensive military deployment, attacking the headquarters of the Palestinian security chief. At least 15 Israeli soldiers were wounded in fighting. Palestinians killed two Israelis in attacks.
Gunmen in the West Bank killed 11 Palestinians suspected of being informers for Israel.

President Bush, facing criticism for his handling of the violence in the Middle East, expressed frustration that Yasir Arafat, the Palestinian leader, had not denounced the ''constant attacks'' of suicide bombers.
Protests against Israel and the United States intensified across the Middle East, with riot police officers in Amman and Cairo employing water cannons and tear gas.
President Hosni Mubarak of Egypt is feeling undermined by Washington, upstaged by Saudi Arabia and vulnerable before an angry Arab population, officials in Cairo say.

France Acts on Anti-Semitism Prime Minister Lionel Jospin said 1,110 extra police officers would be deployed to guard France's synagogues and Jewish schools after two synagogues were destroyed, one by arson and another by firebombs.

U.S. Force-Feeding Captives Who Won't Eat Doctors at the naval base at Guant√°namo Bay, Cuba, have begun force-feeding two prisoners from Afghanistan who had become dangerously malnourished after refusing to eat for most of a month, officials said.

Afghan Drug Shipment Seized The Turkish police and American drug agents seized 7.5 tons of unrefined morphine, worth an estimated $29 million, that was believed to have originated in Afghanistan and passed through Iran, in the biggest drug haul ever in Turkey, officials said.

Lindh Not Linked to Deaths Prosecutors acknowledged that they had no evidence linking John Walker Lindh with the death of any American, but the judge said no direct link with a specific death was necessary to prove that Mr. Lindh had joined a conspiracy to kill Americans.
Enforcing Deportation Orders Federal agents have started to track down and arrest Muslim immigrants who failed to comply with pre-Sept. 11 deportation orders.

Justices Will Review A Three-Strikes Law The Supreme Court agreed to decide whether sentences of 25 years to life in prison imposed under California's three-strikes law are unconstitutionally cruel when the third strike is a minor property crime.
1930 Census Gets Personal The National Archives made public information on individuals and families gathered in the 1930 census, data kept secret by law for 72 years.

Church Settles for $1.2 Million Lori Capobianco Haigh, who says that a Roman Catholic priest in California began sexually abusing her in 1978, when she was 14, and that when she became pregnant at 16 he paid for an abortion, will get $1.2 million.
Wildlife Disease in Midwest Discoveries of sick wildlife in Colorado, Nebraska and Wisconsin raise fear chronic wasting disease may be more widespread than thought.

Dartmouth Killings Case Robert Tulloch, 18, who has pleaded not guilty by reason of insanity in the killings of two Dartmouth professors, will change his plea, most likely to guilty or no contest, lawyers said.
Move to Alter Climate Panel The Bush administration is said to be planning not to reappoint Dr. Robert T. Watson to lead an international panel assessing global warming.

In Towers' Collapse, Echoes of Earlier Disasters A draft of a federal report on the collapse of the twin towers of the World Trade Center notes that some of the problems encountered on Sept. 11 -- like the failure of sprayed-on fireproofing and poor radio communication inside the buildings -- had been encountered and cited in earlier high-rise fires, including one at 1 New York Plaza in August 1970.

CUNY to Get Governors Island President Bush said the federal government would turn over Governors Island to New York in a deal that state and city officials said would allow the former Coast Guard base to be transformed into a CUNY campus.

And This Time She Means It Beverly Sills, 72, said that she would definitely resign as the chairwoman of Lincoln Center on May 1, a move that she has been dissuaded from making before. She will retain a nonvoting seat on the board.
Maryland Takes the Title Maryland beat Indiana, 64-52, to claim the N.C.A.A. national title in men's basketball.
Mets Win Opener at Home The Mets beat Pittsburgh, 6-2, at Shea. The Yankees opened their season with a 10-3 loss in Baltimore.
Security measures took fans by surprise at Shea Stadium, causing many to miss the early innings.

Andersen Rejected Probation The Justice Department was willing to consider deferring or dropping prosecution of Arthur Andersen if it admitted it had illegally destroyed documents and agreed to a form of probation. But executives believed such an admission would be as harmful as an indictment or guilty plea.

Xerox Fined $10 Million Xerox will restate its financial statements dating back to 1997 and pay a $10 million fine to settle a fraud complaint that it expects to be filed by the S.E.C. The fine would be the largest in an S.E.C. enforcement case involving financial reporting.

Adelphia Delays Annual Report Adelphia Communications, which disclosed last week that it had $2.3 billion in debts that it might have to pay but had not put on its balance sheet, said it was delaying its annual report to determine the proper accounting.
Editorials: Time for American leadership; new hope for Governors Island; anticipating another year of the Yankee dynasty. Columns: Paul Krugman, Nicholas D. Kristof.
